statement.tex: %text Write the value of the following integral: \[\qquad\qquad \int_{-\frac\pi{2}}^{\frac\pi{2}}\sin^5 x\cdot dx\] %
\\ %text Your friend makes the following claims about $f(x) = \sin^5 x$ and \[ A = \int_{-\frac\pi{2}}^{\frac\pi{2}}\sin^5x\cdot dx\]. \underline\text{Are his claims correct?} %

options.tex: (\Roman{1})\quad f(x)\text{ is an odd function. } \\ (\Roman{2})\,\therefore A = \int_{-\frac\pi{2}}^{\frac\pi{2}} f(x)\cdot dx = 0
(\Roman{1})\quad f(x)\text{ is an even function. } \\ (\Roman{2})\,\therefore A = \int_{-\frac\pi{2}}^{\frac\pi{2}} f(x)\cdot dx = 2\cdot\int_0^{\frac\pi{2}}f(x)\cdot dx = 2

reason.tex:
%text Whenever you see an integral of the form \[\quad\quad A = \int_{-a}^{+a}f(x)\cdot dx \] ask yourself whether $f(x)$ is \underline\text{odd or even or neither}. Because if it is odd or even, then life is simpler.
In this case, notice that % \begin{align} f(x) &= \sin^5 x = (\sin x)^5 \\ f(-x) &= [\sin (-x)]^5 = \underbrace{(-\sin x)^5}_{\sin(-\theta) = -\sin\theta} \\ &= -\sin^5 x = -f(x) \end{align} \\ %text As $f(-x) = -f(x), f(x)$ \underline\text{is an odd function}. And we know that for odd functions \[ \quad \int_{-a}^{+a}f(x)\cdot dx = 0 \] Hence, \[ A = \int_{-\frac\pi{2}}^{\frac\pi{2}}\sin^5x\cdot dx = 0 \]. %
